title: Robinhood’s Meme-Stock Hangover
description: A year later, many issues linger for the trading app at the center of the frenzy.
content: Twelve months ago, thousands of retail investors banded together to bid up the stocks of a handful of ailing companies, notably the video game retailer GameStop and the movie theater chain AMC. The actions sent those shares soaring, booking huge gains on paper and dealing heavy losses to hedge funds and to other professional investors who were betting against the companies.

title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Voices Pessimism About U.S. Response
description: A Kremlin spokesman said there was “not much cause for optimism.”
content: After the U.S. and NATO presented a written response to Russia’s demands regarding Ukraine, the Kremlin warned that there was “not much cause for optimism.” President Vladimir Putin is taking his time to study the response as fears of a Russian attack on Ukraine grow by the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Feb. 2, 2022
description: The world is buying more and more smartphones, laptops and electric vehicles. A green-energy revolution is taking place. Will we have the rare metals necessary for all the technology products we need?
content: The clean energy revolution is replacing oil and gas with new global commodities: the minerals and metals needed in electric car batteries, solar panels and other forms of renewable energy. Plus, more and more of the technology we buy, from smartphones and laptops to home appliances and toys, are built with these natural resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Don Wilson, Who Gave the Ventures Their Distinctive Rhythm, Dies at 88
description: He was a founder, with Bob Bogle, of what has been called the best-selling and most influential instrumental band in rock ’n’ roll history.
content: Don Wilson, co-founder of the instrumental rock group the Ventures, whose twanging, hard-driving sound, propelled by his dynamic rhythm guitar, led to hits like “Walk — Don’t Run” and helped shape the surf music of the early 1960s as well as influencing generations of guitarists, died on Saturday in Tacoma, Wash. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ISIS Beaten? Not Yet. U.S.-Backed Forces Still Fighting at Syria Prison
description: The Kurdish-led militia claimed prematurely it had retaken a prison captured by the Islamic State. In fact, the battle continues. Up to 90 ISIS fighters remain.
content: HASAKA, Syria — Forces from a Kurdish-led militia traded fire from the rooftops with dozens of Islamic State fighters still holed up in an embattled prison in northeastern Syria on Thursday, despite claims by the U.S.-backed militia a day earlier that it had regained full control of the entire complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainian police arrest a suspect in a shooting at an aerospace and rocket factory.
description: The authorities identified the man as a young national guard soldier and said he opened fire on fellow soldiers “for undetermined reasons.” The site has been a focus of weapons proliferation concerns.
content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — A national guard soldier in Ukraine opened fire early Thursday at an aerospace and rocket factory in the eastern part of the country, killing five people, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Clean’ Review: Taking Out the Trash
description: Adrien Brody plays a community do-gooder with a not-so-pristine past in this action film directed by Paul Solet.
content: Adrien Brody, as Clean, the title protagonist of this movie, drives a sanitation truck with the company name Bliss on its driver-side door in the opening scene. As Clean tools through desolate semi-urban streets in the dead of winter, stopping at the junkyard to feed a wiry dog, it’s clear that right now bliss isn’t part of the man’s program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Lied About My Degree to Get a Job. How Do I Come Clean?
description: A reader who didn’t finish college seeks advice about honesty.
content: I went to college for four years but didn’t finish my degree or graduate because of a mental health issue that was undiagnosed at the time. I am not ashamed of this. But with all my friends graduating, I got nervous about finding a job without a degree. So, I lied about having one when I applied for my first professional job — which I got. The degree is still on my résumé. I am very good at what I do. I have all the skills and abilities my employer wants, and I get excellent performance reviews. Should I tell the truth eventually, and if so, how?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gunman Kills 5 at Ukraine Rocket Factory, Adding to Tensions

content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — A member of the Ukrainian National Guard opened fire at an aerospace and rocket factory on Thursday, killing five people, the authorities said, and raising anxiety in a region already on tenterhooks as tensions with Russia grow.

content: Some had come for the beach, some had come for the sun, others had picked it because, at the time, the Covid numbers seemed reasonable. Many had chosen it over resort destinations because getting there seemed easy. Still others liked the idea of not having to take a test to enter the country.

content: Southwest Airlines on Thursday reported a $68 million profit for the final three months of last year as it struggled to shake off setbacks caused by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, which has delayed the travel recovery and is expected to drag the airline to a loss in the first three months of this year.

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: 8 Lunar New Year Recipes for Good Times Ahead
description: Traditional dishes often symbolize better luck for the future — and they promise a satisfying meal here and now.
content: If Jan. 1 didn’t feel like quite the annual reset you were hoping for, you can celebrate now by cooking for the Lunar New Year, which falls on the day of the first full moon after the winter solstice. For this Year of the Tiger, that’s Feb. 1, and the inaugural feast commences the night before. In China and other Asian countries that recognize the holiday, such as Singapore, Vietnam and South Korea, the festivities can last for two weeks, and the foods often symbolize promises for a better year ahead. But the immediate reward is something delicious to eat, whether you’re preparing a feast or just one dish.

content: Two misfortunes have befallen Stephen G. Breyer during his long Supreme Court career. One, which became apparent about halfway through his nearly 28-year tenure, was that it was his fate to be the quintessential Enlightenment man in an increasingly unenlightened era at the court. The second happened during this past year: the demand from the left that he step down and open his seat for President Biden to fill.

content: Acapulco’s picturesque beauty and grimy desperation converge in writer-director Michel Franco’s psychological thriller “Sundown.” Franco teams up again here with Tim Roth who plays Neil Bennett, an heir to a United Kingdom meatpacking fortune on vacation with his sister, Alice (Charlotte Gainsbourg), and family. description: What life lessons have you learned from your family? What will be your inheritance?
content: “Think About the Beautiful Future Ahead” is a four-minute film that touches on themes of family, loss, sexuality and hope. In this Op-Doc video, Diego Bragà, the filmmaker, shares the story of a beloved uncle and the inheritance made of love he left behind: a plastic box kept in his closet for three decades with photos, drawings, love letters and a collection of postcards exchanged with 160 people from 14 countries and four continents. She did not have a deadline, per se, and nothing to rush for — scurrying is simply how one maneuvers through this section of Midtown Manhattan, through which so many diamonds that enter the United States eventually pass. Ms. Harris, 40, was doing her rounds, picking up and dropping off pieces of her jewelry to polishers, engravers and diamond setters.

content: Welcome. One night last week, cold and tired after a busy day, I craved a very specific comfort food from childhood for dinner: buttered noodles with cottage cheese. It’s cacio e pepe for a toddler’s palate, a very simple variation on mac and cheese, the ultimate comfort food. The meal came together in minutes and hit the spot, as it always does.

content: When Marin Alsop became the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra in 2007, she was the first woman to lead a major orchestra in the United States. Alsop, who concluded her tenure in that position last year, recounts her life in classical music in the documentary “The Conductor,” directed by Bernadette Wegenstein. Alsop’s biography is a story of continually challenging a field in which the sexist idea that women can’t conduct persists.

description: The sequel to the 2010 thriller “La Soga” trades the original’s pointed commentary on crime and corruption for something more generic.

It’s a significant downgrade from the cliché-ridden but visually bracing first installment, transporting Luisito from the streets of his home country (much of the first film was shot in slum areas and working-class neighborhoods in and around Santiago and Baitoa) to a sterile New England town. author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Ben Roethlisberger, Winner of Two Super Bowls, Retires From Pittsburgh Steelers
description: The quarterback, 39, spent all of his 18 seasons in the N.F.L. with the Steelers. His career was overshadowed by injuries and sexual assault allegations.
content: Ben Roethlisberger, the Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback who returned one of the N.F.L.’s legacy franchises to Super Bowl success but whose career was clouded by injuries and sexual assault allegations, announced his retirement from the sport on Thursday after 18 seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany draws mockery for promising 5,000 helmets to help Ukraine defend itself.
description: Critics saw it as a sign of Germany’s reticence to confront Russia. One asked: “What support are they going to send next? Pillows?”
content: BERLIN — After weeks of scrutiny for its less-than-firm diplomatic stance against Russia, the German government announced that it would send 5,000 combat helmets to help Ukraine defend itself in case of an attack by Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: Many children were already asleep when New York ushered in 2022 with fireworks and confetti. On Saturday, however, they don’t have to stay up for commemorations of a different stripe: two events to celebrate the Year of the Tiger, the soon-to-arrive Lunar New Year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Sustainable Thai takeout, a new gallery space in Reykjavik — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Azmat Khan
title: Austin Orders U.S. Military to Step Up Efforts to Prevent Civilian Harm
description: A new directive outlines steps intended to change how commanders think about their jobs, after New York Times investigations into botched airstrikes.
content: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III ordered the military on Thursday to strengthen its efforts to prevent civilian deaths and to improve the way it investigates and acknowledges claims of civilian harm in U.S. combat operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Yes, Omicron Is Loosening Its Hold. But the Pandemic Has Not Ended.
description: With spotty immunity in the population and a churn of new variants, the coronavirus is likely to become a persistent but hopefully manageable threat.
content: After a frenetic few weeks when the Omicron variant of the coronavirus seemed to infect everyone, including the vaccinated and boosted, the United States is finally seeing encouraging signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches 2 Ballistic Missiles, South Korea Says
description: It was the North’s ​sixth missile test this month, the South Korean military said.
content: SEOUL — North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on ​Thursday ​in its ​sixth missile test this month, the South Korean military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld, William K. Rashbaum and Jan Ransom
title: Bribery Case Casts a Shadow Over Eric Adams’s Public Safety Chief
description: Despite once being ensnared in a federal corruption investigation, Philip Banks III will play a central role in the mayor’s plan to reduce gun violence.
content: His voice was recorded on federal wiretaps. His luxury overseas trips were scrutinized. His massages, golf outings and steak dinners were carefully cataloged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jussie Smollett Sentencing Is Set for March 10
description: The actor, convicted in the filing of a false police report that said he had been the victim of a racist and homophobic attack, faces a maximum sentence of three years in prison.
content: A judge in Chicago on Thursday set March 10 as the date on which the actor Jussie Smollett will be sentenced following his conviction in the filing of a false police report in which he claimed to have been the victim of a racist and homophobic attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple’s profit jumps to $34.6 billion in holiday quarter despite supply issues.
description: The company’s revenue and profit beat Wall Street expectations, easing concerns that supply chain problems and the coronavirus were a drag on sales.
content: Apple weathered the supply chain snarls at the end of 2021 that tripped up the global electronics market and other industries, announcing on Thursday an 11 percent increase in revenue and a 20 percent jump in profit in its most recent quarter while offering optimism that the worst of the problems were behind it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: incontrovertible
description: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: At City Ballet, Jamar Roberts and Dancers Find a Common Language
description: “I was thinking about Balanchine a lot,” said Roberts, Ailey’s choreographer in residence, who is making his first work for New York City Ballet.
content: So much has happened since Jamar Roberts was to have had his choreographic debut at New York City Ballet, in May 2020. Before he had even set foot in the studio with the dancers, the pandemic shut everything down. Then came a national period of soul searching around the issue of race brought on by the killing of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Nissan and Renault seek stronger ties with a commitment to electric cars.
description: The two automakers and Mitsubishi plan to strengthen their alliance by adding 35 electric models to their lineups by 2030.
content: Nissan, Renault and Mitsubishi announced on Thursday that they would band together to make substantial new investments in electric cars as they seek to leverage their sometimes fractious alliance to compete in the global market for battery-powered vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Bronxville, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Upper Freehold, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: East Coast Braces for Snow Again
description: A winter storm watch was in effect from eastern North Carolina up to New England. Meteorologists said that slight changes in the storm’s track could shift snow totals drastically.
content: A sprawling storm system that is forecast to bring winter weather from North Carolina to New England this weekend could have a “significant” impact as it moves up the East Coast, a meteorologist said on Thursday, warning of a storm that could snarl traffic along the Interstate 95 corridor and threaten power outages to millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Reflects on Stephen Breyer’s Retirement Plan
description: “Yep, at 83, Breyer only has two options: either retire or play quarterback for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers,” Jimmy Fallon said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden plans to name Breyer’s successor by the end of February.
description: Speaking with Justice Stephen Breyer by his side, Mr. Biden hailed his decades on the federal bench, including almost 28 years on the Supreme Court.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Thursday that he would name a successor for Justice Stephen G. Breyer by the end of February, calling the retiring jurist “a model public servant in a time of great division” and pledging to take what he called the overdue step of putting a Black woman on the court for the first time in its 232-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Want to Be a Writer? Get Your Training as a Wedding Planner.
description: Before Xochitl Gonzalez wrote her best-selling debut novel, “Olga Dies Dreaming,” she produced elaborate events. The experience was invaluable.
content: HERE COMES THE SCRIBE There was the bride who instructed a makeup artist to make her bridesmaids look like “little piggies” so they wouldn’t steal the spotlight. There was the couple who dreamed of transforming a summer camp in Maine into a luxury venue for their nuptials. There was the wedding where a grandparent suffered a heart attack, prompting a second (impromptu, unrehearsed) procession — firefighters followed by the police followed by paramedics. And of course, there were the newlyweds who traded vicious barbs and the divorced parents who refused to find common ground and the many moments of kismet and serendipity one would expect when two people say “I do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert C. Yeager
title: 3 Little Words to Send a Lamborghini on Its Way
description: A novel navigation system, What3words, will be standard on new Huracán models. It divides the globe into 57 trillion 10-foot squares, and leads you to one.
content: In most modern cars and S.U.V.s, dashboard navigation systems help motorists plot a road trip, give them a route to client meetings or lead them to their children’s away soccer games. But where is a Lamborghini Huracán driver headed?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Lauren Smith-Fields Was Found Dead. Her Family Had to Beg for Answers.
description: Ms. Smith-Fields, 23, died in her Connecticut apartment in December after a date with a man she had met on Bumble. More than a month later, the police opened a criminal investigation.
content: Shantell Fields had not heard from her daughter all day. “Are you OK?” Ms. Fields texted. “Please let me know.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Disney’s Former C.E.O. Gave Me the Exit Interview I Asked for
description: The recently retired Disney executive talks about how Star Wars helped Disney survive the streaming wars and why NFTs are here to stay.
content: Bob Iger’s recent retirement from Disney marks a sea change for the company. Starting at ABC nearly 50 years ago, Iger ascended from working at a local news network to serving as the chief executive and chairman of Disney, ABC’s owner. During that time, he navigated tectonic shifts in Hollywood, including the rise of streaming platforms and the fall of movie chains. So Kara Swisher dragged Iger out of his three weeks of retirement to chat more about the future of entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: School Board in Tennessee Bans Teaching of Holocaust Novel ‘Maus’
description: The board voted unanimously to remove the Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel from classrooms because it contained swear words, according to minutes from the meeting.
content: A school board in Tennessee voted unanimously this month to ban “Maus,” a Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel about the Holocaust, from being taught in its classrooms because the book contains material that board members said was inappropriate for students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Shesol
title: The Willful Naïveté of Stephen Breyer
description: He insisted that politics do not shape the decisions of justices — an idyllic, even naïve, notion, but one that kept the court functioning for years.
content: At a campaign stop in late October 1932, Franklin D. Roosevelt, then the Democratic candidate for president, remarked that the Republican Party had “complete control of all branches of government.” As Roosevelt saw it, this was a simple statement of fact: The G.O.P. had controlled the White House and Congress for years, and the Supreme Court was dominated by Republican appointees. Yet the response, from leading members of the bar, was swift and indignant. “The Supreme Court,” scoffed a prominent lawyer, “is above and beyond politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Are New Voting Bill Talks for Real or for Show?
description: Senators involved in the negotiations underway say the discussions are serious and substantive, but some Democrats remain wary.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, was finally closing in on a hard-fought agreement with Republicans on a gun safety measure, following a string of horrific shootings in 2019, when the talks suddenly collapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: W. Kamau Bell takes account of Bill Cosby. And Jonathan Van Ness takes a journey through his passions.
content: ‘We Need to Talk About Cosby’When to Watch: Sunday at 10 p.m., on Showtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Take This Hot Flash and Shove It!
description: Hot flashes, mood swings and other signs of menopause can cause women to quit their jobs. Here’s how some handle symptoms while working.
content: Menopause — and the years leading up to it — can disrupt women’s lives in so many ways, including, new findings suggest, by upending their livelihoods. A British survey of 2,000 women between the ages of 45 and 67 reported last week that one in four women experiencing symptoms of menopause were unhappy in their jobs because of a lack of support, and that nearly one in five were considering quitting because of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: ‘Jeopardy!’ Hasn’t Had a Player Like Amy Schneider
description: The most successful woman to compete on the show can finally celebrate her 40-day winning streak. And the money.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Amy Schneider’s 40-day “Jeopardy!” winning streak ended, she said she handed out thank you notes to the crew, briefly chatted with other contestants, then excused herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: After Breyer
description: The latest on the coming Supreme Court nomination.
content: Stephen Breyer has just done something that liberal Supreme Court justices in the modern era don’t always do: He has timed his retirement so that an ideologically similar justice is likely to replace him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who Controls the Past Controls the Future
description: Lewis Rothlein and Jeff Chen double down.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Administrivial Alert: Thanks for the bug report on 35A. It has been fixed on the web game (if it still looks incorrect to you, please try refreshing the page). For those who are still seeing the old version in the app, please go to the crossword archive, long press on the puzzle and then choose “update” on the pop up. The new version should appear.Also, if you are solving in the Android app, please go into Settings and make sure that the “Show overlays” button is set to “on.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Rabbi Israel Dresner, Civil Rights Champion and King Ally, Dies at 92
description: He was jailed multiple times in the South during the 1960s and made human rights his lifelong cause, following the Jewish doctrine of “tikkun olam” — to repair the world.
content: Israel S. Dresner, a New Jersey rabbi who ventured into the Deep South in the 1960s to champion civil rights, befriended the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and was jailed multiple times for demonstrating against racial segregation, died on Jan. 13 in Wayne, N.J. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Michael Rothfeld
title: Eric Adams Can Hire His Brother, but at Salary of $1, Not $210,000
description: Instead of overseeing the mayor’s security detail, Bernard Adams will be a senior adviser to the mayor with no supervisory role after an ethics board ruling.
content: When a furor erupted over Mayor Eric Adams’s decision to hire his brother to manage his security detail, the mayor retroactively sought formal guidance from the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board and vowed to abide by its determination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Despite Burnout, These California Health Care Workers Aren’t Quitting
description: Nurses and doctors say they don’t want to abandon their co-workers or their patients.
content: As I explored in yesterday’s newsletter, nurses and doctors in California are burned out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Diplomatic attempts to resolve the situation with Russia.
content: The U.S. and NATO gave formal responses yesterday to Russia’s demands that NATO pull back forces from Eastern Europe and bar Ukraine from ever joining the alliance. The U.S. response “sets out a serious diplomatic path forward should Russia choose it,” the secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Origin Story: How a Comics Reporter Uncovers Marvels
description: In a comic about reporting on comics, a Times journalist takes you through his process — from idea to pitch to research and writing.
content: This comic, by the Times reporter George Gene Gustines and the artist Bill Walko, is part of our ongoing journalism and news literacy series. You can find an accompanying lesson plan here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: F.C.C. revokes the ability of China Unicom to operate in the U.S.
description: The agency cited national security in revoking the license for the American subsidiary of a state-owned Chinese telecom operator.
content: The Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that a state-owned Chinese telecom operator can no longer operate in the United States for national security reasons, as officials in Washington go further to limit the influence of Chinese companies over American consumers, businesses and communications networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Botticelli Sold for $45.4 Million at Sotheby’s Auction
description: The painting, which last sold in 1963 for $26,000, was part of a sale of works by old masters.
content: A long-overlooked painting regarded for decades as the work of Sandro Botticelli’s studio assistants sold at Sotheby’s in New York on Thursday for $45.4 million with fees, kick-starting this year’s cycle of headline-grabbing prices for trophy artworks at auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Jordan’s Army Kills 27 in Drug Bust on Syrian Border
description: The Jordanian Army said that soldiers fired on suspected smugglers as they tried to cross the border under cover of a snowstorm.
content: Jordanian troops killed 27 people they described as armed drug smugglers who were trying to cross the border from Syria under cover of a snowstorm Thursday, a spokesman for the Jordanian Army said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: It’s Time for an Honest Conversation About Affirmative Action
description: Should we rethink how colleges use racial preferences?
content: On Monday, the Supreme Court announced it would hear arguments in Students for Fair Admissions v. President and Fellows of Harvard College. In 2014, the group sued the university, accusing it of discriminating against Asian students during its admissions process. After years of court filings and an actual trial, S.F.F.A. ultimately lost its case but immediately appealed to the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Did I Turn Off the Stove? Yes, but Maybe Not the Gas
description: New research finds that gas stoves emit methane, a potent greenhouse gas, even when turned off and adds to the debate over electrifying homes.
content: Gas stoves leak significant amounts of methane when they are being ignited and even while they are turned off, according to a new report, adding to the growing debate over the effects of gas-powered appliances on human health and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan L. O'Sullivan and Jason Bordoff
title: Russia Isn’t a Dead Petrostate, and Putin Isn’t Going Anywhere
description: The transition to cleaner energy will make it possible  for petrostates to wield significant geopolitical and economic power.
content: If you were wondering whether Europe is running out of options to deal with its continuing energy crisis, one of Britain’s largest energy suppliers just offered an answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Two former Deutsche Bank traders win their appeal in a Libor manipulation case.
description: But ruling is another indication of the difficulty prosecutors have had making the case that traders at a handful of big banks conspired to profit from manipulating Libor, the benchmark once used by banks to set interest rates.
content: The decade-long pursuit of holding Wall Street accountable for trying to manipulate Libor, the once-prominent interest rate benchmark, suffered another blow Thursday when a federal appeals court overturned the convictions of two former Deutsche Bank traders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Clare Toeniskoetter, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Corey Schreppel
title: Biden Gets a Supreme Court Pick
description: Why Justice Stephen Breyer is retiring now, and how President Biden is likely to go about choosing his successor.
content: On Wednesday, it was revealed that Justice Stephen Breyer, the senior member of the Supreme Court’s liberal wing, will retire from the bench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Ashleigh Barty and Danielle Collins Will Meet in Australian Open Final
description: Cheered by a home crowd, the top-ranked Barty defeated Madison Keys in straight sets to become the first Australian to reach the women’s final since 1980. Collins enjoyed her own straight sets win over Iga Swiatek.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — It is all about choices, this game of tennis and life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: A top SoftBank deputy is leaving after a billion-dollar pay dispute.
description: Marcelo Claure became a close confidant of SoftBank’s founder and played a singular role at the Japanese conglomerate. He was seeking roughly $2 billion over several years.
content: SoftBank announced on Friday that Marcelo Claure, a top deputy to the company’s founder, Masayoshi Son, will step down as its chief operating officer. The exit comes after a dispute over roughly $2 billion in possible compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘A Taste of Hunger’ Review: A Relentless Pursuit of Perfection
description: A husband and wife pour everything into their restaurant in a quest for a Michelin star, heedless of the other dimensions of their lives.
content: In the Danish drama “A Taste of Hunger” infidelity and unyielding ambition threaten to derail the relationship between a married couple of restaurateurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Brighton 4th’ Review: Family Bonds, Guilt and Gumption
description: In this Georgian film, an aging ex-wrestler (played by an aging ex-wrestler) travels to Brooklyn to help his wayward son.
content: Georgia’s cinematic exports have bloomed recently with innovative and challenging films such as “What Do We See When We Look at the Sky?,” “Beginning” and “Taming the Garden.” Levan Koguashvili’s “Brighton 4th” offers a more straightforward style of storytelling as it sends an aging ex-wrestler from the capital city of Tbilisi to Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, to help his wayward son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: How Are People Spending Their Home-Equity Loans?
description: A study reveals the most popular plans for home equity dollars in large U.S. metro areas.
content: As property values skyrocketed through 2021, homeowners in the United States found themselves with a lot more home equity — and historically low interest rates gave them extra incentive to turn the equity into cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Phone Booth in the Wilderness
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A #MeToo Moment Shakes Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox
description: An acclaimed religious children’s author was accused of abusing women and children. Then he killed himself, sending shock waves through the conservative community.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: ‘From Worst to Best’: Gleaming New La Guardia Terminal Opens
description: The airport that Joe Biden once said was more suited to a “third-world’’ country has a gleaming new terminal to show off.
content: For decades, La Guardia Airport was one of the most maligned airports in the country — leaky ceilings, cramped corridors, regular rodent sightings and broken escalators set a standard for the dreadful travel experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A New Ethical Debate Looms for the Baseball Hall of Fame
description: Some controversial players have fallen off the ballot, but with Carlos Beltrán expected to be a finalist next year, a different form of cheating will be in the spotlight.
content: It might have been the best game Jim Palmer ever pitched: 11 scoreless innings on a summer afternoon in Baltimore in 1977, with nine strikeouts and no walks. Palmer didn’t win it, though, because the Orioles never scored. Gaylord Perry, the slippery ace of the Texas Rangers, was dominant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: The Hot New Thing in Dating? Actually Going on Dates.
description: Long, aimless conversations on apps have led fatigued singles back to the basics: meeting IRL.
content: Last Thursday night, 10 people were lined up for admission to Hair of the Dog, a sports bar on the Lower East Side that usually draws crowds for Sunday football viewing and day drinking. When they reached the bouncer, each was asked to provide documentation for entry: government-issued ID, proof of vaccination and a dating app profile, not that any of them were there to swipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Questions of Power and Process After Harassment Claim at FIFA
description: The head of the star-studded FIFA Legends program was found to have sexually harassed a subordinate in 2019. The victim still isn’t sure he was ever punished.
content: Miguel Macedo had shown his value to soccer’s top leader for months. Now, on the morning of Gianni Infantino’s first day as FIFA president, Macedo would demonstrate his connections, and his usefulness, once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: ‘He Stole From Me’: Stormy Daniels Testifies at Avenatti Trial
description: Michael Avenatti is representing himself at his trial in Manhattan and started to cross-examine Ms. Daniels personally.
content: Stormy Daniels, the pornographic film star whose lawsuit against former President Donald J. Trump was at the center of a 2018 scandal, took the stand as a witness on Thursday in the trial of Michael Avenatti, the lawyer who once represented her but now stands accused of stealing from her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Inefficient Goodbye Kiss
description: A married couple disagree on how to leave for work.
content: Kris writes: My husband and I keep very different schedules, which is fine. But I seek a ruling that if my husband gets up before me, he should say goodbye and give me a kiss on the forehead to let me know he’s leaving. If he doesn’t, I wake up and panic that he has died, left forever or gotten lost. He says I should know he’s OK and he shouldn’t have to add a step to his routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: San Jose Moves to Require Gun Owners to Have Insurance and Pay Annual Fees
description: A proposed ordinance, believed to be the first of its kind in the U.S., calls for an annual “harm reduction fee” of about $25 to pay for programs to stem gun violence.
content: Gun owners in San Jose, Calif., may soon be required to carry liability insurance and to pay an annual fee for suicide prevention and other safety programs intended to reduce gun violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Can Biden Avert a Crisis With North Korea?
description: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has done six missile tests this month — equal to all of 2021 — and called on the nation to prepare for “long-term confrontation.”
content: WASHINGTON — After North Korea ushered in the new year with four sets of ballistic missile tests this month, the Biden administration turned to a well-thumbed page in the Washington playbook: It called for more United Nations sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: Biden Gets to Name a New Supreme Court Justice
description: Plus, Tucker Carlson assures us that he’s “not an agent of Russia.”
content: Justice Stephen Breyer’s retirement is big news for the Supreme Court. It’s less clear how much of an effect it will have on the midterm elections — though the court’s expected rulings on abortion and other hot-button issues could certainly shape the debate going into the midterms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Martyrs, Converts and Pious Frauds: Religion Takes Center Stage
description: Three Paris productions — including Ivo van Hove’s take on “Tartuffe” at the Comédie-Française — explore questions of the divine.
content: PARIS — When Molière first presented “Tartuffe,” in 1664, Louis XIV is said to have laughed his head off at the play’s satire of religious zealots. The zealots in question were less amused: “Tartuffe” was swiftly censored and only re-emerged five years later, in an expanded and softened version.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Transportation Dept. Outlines Plan to Address Rising Traffic Deaths
description: The department said it would use new funding in the infrastructure law to carry out the strategy, which touches on issues ranging from speed limits to emergency medical care.
content: WASHINGTON — The Transportation Department is embarking on a national strategy to tackle rising traffic fatalities using new funding in the $1 trillion infrastructure law, addressing issues ranging from speed limits and street lighting to emergency medical care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill McKibben
title: A Deer in the Headlights: ‘Bambi’ Reconsidered
description: As a new translation makes clear, this tale of survival, written between the wars by an Austro-Hungarian Jew, wasn’t intended for young children.
content: THE ORIGINAL BAMBIThe Story of a Life in the ForestBy Felix SaltenTranslated and introduced by Jack ZipesIllustrated by Alenka Sottler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: In Dog DNA, Small Size Has an Ancient Pedigree
description: New research finds a mutation that suggests the more diminutive canines’ DNA dates back to ancient wolves.
content: Big dogs get all the glory. I don’t have a peer-reviewed paper to prove it, but I can quote the greatest country singer of all time, Hank Williams, who is certainly some kind of authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: A coronavirus case in Beijing’s Olympic bubble is linked to a German team.
description: A supervisor who tested positive is asymptomatic and is now in a quarantine hotel, the German Olympic Sports Confederation said.
content: A supervisor in Germany’s Olympic delegation has tested positive for the coronavirus within the closed loop in Beijing, the German Olympic Sports Confederation said on Thursday, confirming one of the first cases connected to an athletic team within the bubblelike environment meant to shield participants from the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: For the Manhattan D.A., a New Emphasis on Gun Crime
description: Alvin Bragg, who campaigned on lenient policies, appointed a prosecutor dedicated to preventing gun violence.

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘They/Them/Us’ Review: Working Out the Kinks
description: In this dramatic comedy, two divorced 40-somethings gamely experiment with B.D.S.M.
content: It’s all too easy to turn a fetish into broad comedy — the more peculiar the fetish, the better it lends itself to glib, obvious jokes. The best thing about “They/Them/Us,” a dramatic comedy about two divorced 40-somethings wading into B.D.S.M., is that it largely resists this temptation. There are a couple of routine gags involving stuff like double-sided dildos and ill-fitting leather pants, but for the most part the movie treats bondage and discipline as ordinary, fulfilling pastimes for consenting adults. “Whatever you see, don’t laugh,” a dominatrix warns Charlie (Joey Slotnick), before he attends his first kink festival. It’s refreshing that the director Jon Sherman heeds this advice and doesn’t default to mockery around these things either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rose
title: David Byrne, the Artist, Is Totally Connected
description: There’s a new gallery show and book of his whimsical line drawings — and coming this summer, an immersive art-and-science experience.
content: David Byrne is all about connectedness these days. “Everybody’s  coming to my house/And I’m never gonna be alone,” he sings on Broadway in “American Utopia,” half joyful, half fretful, still open. His online magazine, “Reasons to Be Cheerful” — which bills itself as “a tonic for tumultuous times” — catalogs all the ways in which people are pulling together to make sure the world does not in fact go to hell in a handbasket. And on Feb. 2, he reprises this theme of connectedness at Pace Gallery in Chelsea with a show of 48 whimsical line drawings that span 20 years of art making, from his “tree” series of the early ’00s to the “dingbats” he made in lockdown in 2020-2021.

content: When the latest round of meat analogues first hit the market, I was so excited to try them. But for me, a real, high-quality, well-seasoned veggie burger — that is to say, a homemade patty, built with a mix of beans, mushrooms, vegetables, grains or tofu — tends to be way more interesting, more satisfying and more delicious.

author: By Donika Kelly and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Self-Portrait With Father
description: A heartbreaking ending points to the selective memory of trauma.
content: In “Self-Portrait With Father,” the speaker calls a meeting (real or imagined) with the abusive father. The diction is matter-of-fact, the syntax conventional; the imagery is simple and bare-boned. Even the form of the poem is in steely couplets. “You can stop,” the speaker says, toward the end of the poem. Note that this italicized line sits in isolation, evoking both loneliness and agency. The heartbreaking ending points to the selective memory of trauma. The speaker doesn’t remember everything but knows one tragic thing for certain — that the father fails in stopping his abuse. Selected by Victoria Chang
